I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  As agreed on with the Government of Nepal during the Country Program Mission in April 
2003,  a  nonlending  program  on  Strengthening  Performance-Based  Management  has  been 
included in the Asian Development Bank (ADB) country program for Nepal for 2003.1 This 
program will provide technical assistance (TA) support to implement a critical component of the 
ADB-assisted Governance Reform Program (GRP).2  During the Nepal 2003 Country Program 
Mission,  the  Government  and  ADB  agreed  that  progress  in  establishing  processes  for 
performance-based management in key ministries would be used as a monitoring indicator to 
assess Nepal’s lending scenario.  
 
2.  A TA Fact-Finding Mission was fielded from 14 to 24 July 2003. The Mission reached an 
understanding with the Government on the objectives, scope, costs, financing, implementation 
arrangements, and terms of reference for consulting services under the TA. The TA framework 
is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The Government has prioritized governance reform as critical for economic development 
and poverty reduction. The Tenth Plan, which is also the Government’s poverty reduction 
strategy paper, has adopted a four-pillar poverty reduction strategy, including good governance. 
A number of government policies, including recent budget speeches, a report of the Public 
Expenditure  Review  Commission,  and  several  administrative  reform  commissions  have 
stressed  the  need  for  public  management  to  be  more  pro-public,  efficient,  transparent, 
responsive, and accountable. ADB has supported the Government’s governance reform effort 
since 1998. A TA3 was approved in December 1998 to prepare an action plan on civil service 
reform. A subsequent TA4 helped the Government start its long-term reform program and further 
assess  options  and  priorities  to  implement  the  reform  program.  The  TA  also  helped  the 
Government implement the first stages of the policy-based GRP to meet the program loan’s 
first-tranche conditions.  
 
4.  GRP was approved on 27 November 2001. Its overall goal is to establish a civil service 
that is result and people oriented and gender responsive, and will help achieve higher economic 
growth and reduce poverty. The objectives of GRP are to (i) develop the Government’s capacity 
to lead and undertake the governance reform agenda, (ii) improve the efficiency of the civil 
service,  (iii)  improve  governance  and  reduce  government  corruption,  (iv)  enhance  the 
competence  and  motivation  of  civil  servants,  and  (v)  establish  processes  to  improve 
performance in key ministries. The Executing Agency for the program loan is the Ministry of 
General Administration (MOGA), with the administrative reform committee5 (ARC) chaired by 
the minister for general administration and with key government officials as members, to guide 
GRP implementation. The Government also established five reform units to lead and drive the 
reform program: governance reform coordination unit (GRCU) in MOGA; efficiency unit in the

5.  Three TA packages were proposed6 to implement GRP: (i) package 1: core program 
reform;  (ii)  package  2:  civil-society  support  for  the  reform  measures;  and  (iii)  package  3: 
program  monitoring  and  reporting.  During  GRP  loan  negotiation  in  November  2001,  ADB 
agreed that the Government would secure funding from other donor agencies to finance the 
packages,  given  ADB’s  TA  resource  constraints.  ADB  has  since  continued  to  help  the 
Government  seek  cofinancing  from  bilateral  donor  agencies.  The  Swiss  Agency  for 
Development and Cooperation (SDC) has confirmed funding support for packages 2 and 3, with 
Pro-Public, a local nongovernment organization (NGO) contracted to implement the two TAs 
since July 2003.  
 
6.  Package 1 comprises five reform components that encompass the five GRP objectives. 
The Government has been implementing a number of these reform components based on 
proposals developed by TA (footnote 4). The Government is also seeking donor support to 
implement  other  reform  components  of  this  package.  For  example,  the  United  Nations 
Development Programme (UNDP) Mainstreaming Gender Equity Programme has supported 
gender-mainstreaming  programs.  The  United  Kingdom’s  Department  for  International 
Development (DFID) has indicated an interest in supporting programs on gender and exclusion. 
MOGA and DFID held several meetings recently to draw up terms of reference to prepare a 
project document. However, the Government has not been able to secure TA support for the 
performance improvement component of package 1 despite requests to DFID and United States 
Agency for International Development (USAID). Implementing policy measures and activities of 
this reform component has been delayed and, as a result, GRP implementation is suffering. Any 
further delay could seriously undermine the program’s intended benefits. Reform in performance 
management is an integral part of GRP since it is concerned with delivery of improved services 
to citizens and, therefore, is directly related to making Nepal’s civil service more result and 
people oriented. Reform in performance management was sequenced toward the end of the 
first phase of GRP (early 2003), as other reform initiatives7 under the program were expected to 
complement the introduction of a performance management system. Since SDC’s TA (para. 5) 
will  mainly  focus  on  building  stakeholder  support  for  reform  initiatives  under  performance 
management, the policy measures and activities under performance improvement component 
need to be implemented immediately. Disbursement of GRP’s second and third loan tranches is 
linked  to  effective  implementation  of  a  number  of  policy  measures  and  actions  under  the 
performance management component.  
 
7.    GRP’s design envisaged that a subsequent TA would complement the preliminary work 
initiated by TA on performance management (footnote 4). The TA consultants organized a 
number of consultative workshops8 for members of the reform units, and helped MOGA, MOAC, 
and MOES develop performance improvement plans, including service delivery indicators. The 
consultants developed a model9 for performance-based management in the civil service and an

inadequate understanding of performance management, service delivery standards, and funds. 
The  Government  requested  further  consultancy  support  in  this  area,  while  the  Mission 
recognized that further work would be difficult without additional expatriate consultancy support.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
9.  The TA’s objective is to help the Government implement GRP’s reform component to 
improve the quality, efficiency, and access of services provided by key ministries. The TA’s 
purpose is to establish a system to develop, adopt, communicate, and monitor performance 
targets in selected service and central ministries, with a first set of targets in place by the end of 
the TA. It will deliver a performance management system, performance improvement plans, 
performance improvement fund, and service standards. Emphasis will be placed on building 
skills, confidence, and change leadership in GRCU, efficiency unit, and the change units in the 
three pilot ministries. The TA will also help the Government meet second- and third-tranche 
conditions under GRP’s performance improvement component, as specified in its policy matrix. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA’s central focus will be to establish and implement the culture and processes 
related  to  performance-based  management,  and  demonstrate  budget  incentives,  efficiency 
dividends, and benefits in terms of improved outcomes. The TA will support three service 
delivery ministries (MOAC, MOES, and MOH) and two central ministries (MOF and MOGA), and 
review the work initiated on performance management by TA (footnote 4). GRCU and efficiency 
unit will develop management performance plans and transfer new procedures and capacities to 
support the three pilot line ministries. The TA will provide GRCU, efficiency unit, and the change 
units with customized training and mentoring to ensure that leadership and technical skills are 
available to develop and implement management and performance plans. Management and in-
service training will be provided to develop the skills needed to analyze problems and design 
solutions to help improve ministry performance as specified in the performance improvement 
plans.  
 
11.  The TA will help MOAC, MOES, and MOH develop and implement annual performance 
improvement plans, including client service standards. The Government will work in partnership

be a key feature of plans to facilitate reform and provide incentives for the ministries. To access 
these savings, a performance improvement fund12 will be introduced in a phased manner and 
provided  to  ministries  that  successfully  introduce  performance  improvement  plans.  The 
performance fund will be used for skills development, improved business processes, engaging 
specialist staff, and equipment purchase. The TA will help MOF and MOGA design institutional 
arrangements, modalities, and procedures to implement such a fund.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $330,000 equivalent, of which the foreign exchange cost is 
$180,000  and  the  local  currency  is  $150,000  equivalent.  The  Government  has  requested 
$275,000, to be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program to cover the entire 
foreign exchange cost of $180,000 and $95,000 equivalent of the local currency costs. The 
Government has agreed to contribute the remaining local currency cost of $55,000 equivalent to 
provide office accommodation and travel, counterpart staff support, facilities for seminars and 
meetings, and other administrative expenses. Details of cost estimates and the financing plan 
are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  MOGA will be the Executing Agency for the TA. GRCU will coordinate and monitor TA 
activities, and report to the ARC through the MOGA secretary. GRCU, efficiency unit, and the 
change units will direct and support reform in their respective ministries. The Government will 
provide progress reports on TA implementation in line with reporting arrangements of GRP. Pro-
Public will independently assess the impact of service delivery efforts based on consumer 
surveys (under TA package 2).  
 
14.  The TA will be implemented over 15 months, from December 2003 to February 2005, 
and have a total of 21 person-months of consultancy: 6 international and 15 domestic, with 
international expertise input provided in two phases. The consultancy team, with expertise in 
performance  management,  will  include  one  international  and  one  domestic  consultant;  the 
international consultant will lead the team. The international consultant will have extensive 
experience in developing civil service performance improvement schemes. The consultants will 
be recruited on an individual basis. The consultants will be selected and engaged in accordance 
with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  by  ADB  and  its  Borrowers  and  other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. The outline 
terms of reference of the consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
15.  The consultants will submit five brief progress reports: an inception report no later than 4 
weeks after fielding the consultants, a progress report in the fourth month, a midterm progress 
report in the seventh month, a progress report in the eleventh month, a draft final report in the

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance, on a grant basis, to the Government of Nepal in an amount 
not exceeding the equivalent of $275,000 for the purpose of Strengthening Performance-Based 
Management, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Services 
1.  The scope of service of the consultants (6 person-months of international expertise and 
15 person-months of domestic expertise) requires expertise in performance management. An 
international consultant with expertise in introducing performance management schemes in the 
civil service will lead the consultancy team since experience and capacity in implementing 
performance management systems is limited in Nepal. The consultants will assess the skill 
levels and needs of line ministry personnel and management in relation to preparation of 
performance improvement plans (for the ministries of agriculture and cooperatives, health, and 
education  and  sports),  and  will  provide  direction  on  covering  areas  directly  relevant  to 
production of the plan. The consultants will provide training, produce the plans, and facilitate 
implementation.  The  consultants  will  also  help  the  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF),  Ministry  of 
General Administration (MOGA), and three line ministries design institutional frameworks and 
operating procedures to establish and use the performance improvement fund. The consultants 
will  help  the  staff  of  the  governance  reform  coordination  and  efficiency  units  develop 
management improvement plans that cover the critical operations and business processes of 
MOGA and MOF, respectively, in addition to support to line ministries. The consultants will help 
the Government meet the second- and third-tranche loan conditions under the performance 
improvement component of the Governance Reform Program (GRP), as specified in its policy 
matrix;  therefore,  the  consultants  will  need  to  comprehend  GRP’s  principles  and  policy 
framework. The consultants will primarily facilitate adoption of a process consultancy approach, 
enabling reforms to be carried out by government personnel. The performance management 
consultants will report to the secretary of MOGA.  
 
B.  International Consultants  
 
2.  The consultants will do the following: 
 
(i)  Jointly with the Government review the TA (footnote 4) consultants’ work on 
performance  management  and  identify  areas  of  work  that  can  be  further 
developed and implemented. 
(ii)  Collaboratively assess competencies and strengths of line ministry management 
and staff to prepare and implement performance improvement plans oriented to 
improved service delivery (including service delivery to remote ethnic minority 
communities) against set standards. 
(iii)  Based on the assessment, conduct training sessions to improve skill levels, and 
produce performance improvement plans (to include service delivery to minor 
communities) based on the agreed-on formats. 
(iv)  Coach, mentor, and guide line ministry personnel in performance improvement 
plan  implementation,  including  development  and  introduction  of  service 
standards. 
(v)  Help MOF and MOGA staff develop formal management improvement plans. 
(vi)  Advise and guide MOF, MOGA, and the line ministries in implementing plans, 
particularly in overcoming obstacles, and using new management techniques, 
business processes, and formal reporting. 
(vii)  Help MOF, MOGA, and the line ministries establish guidelines to create and use 
the performance improvement fund.
